description: Judge Lance A. Ito today barred O. J. Simpson's lawyers from advancing their theory, which he called "highly speculative," that Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald L. Goldman were killed by drug dealers whose real target was Faye Resnick, Mrs. Simpson's friend and, for a time, an admitted cocaine user.

title: 2 Indicted in Counselor's Death
description: It has been almost six months since Robert Heavey died after he was injured during a disturbance at the Morris County Youth Center, where he was a part-time counselor. Mr. Heavey was punched above the eye during a Jan. 3 melee. He later slipped into a coma. Two youths who were being held in the center on robbery charges at the time of the melee were indicted yesterday in Mr. Heavey's death. Kevin Harrington and Delfon Robins face life sentences.

title: Paris Journal; A Breath of Fresh Air? Don't Stroll by the Seine
description: It has been one of France's best-kept secrets but the painful truth is out: Paris, the capital of food, fashion and fragrance, a civilized island in a deteriorating world, has joined the ranks of the polluted cities.

title: Sanders Now a Part of Air Marino
description: Wide receiver RICKY SANDERS, the nine-year pro who played for Atlanta last season, signed a two-year deal with the Miami Dolphins yesterday. Sanders joins RANDAL HILL and the former Washington Redskin GARY CLARK as free agent receivers signed by the Dolphins since last season. IRVING FRYAR and O. J. McDUFFIE are Miami's top returning receivers. Sanders is eager to team with quarterback DAN MARINO. "I can hardly sleep at night getting ready to catch balls from this guy," Sanders said. (AP)

title: Democrat Won't Rule Out Sharing Power in Myanmar
description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the newly freed opposition leader, said today that she did not rule out a transitional government in which the Burmese military shared political power with civilians, insisting that she had a "soft spot" for the military even though it held her under house arrest for nearly six years.

title: W.T. O'Donnell, 72, Executive Who Guided Expansion at Bally
description: William T. O'Donnell, who engineered the rise of the Bally Manufacturing Corporation from a manufacturer of pinball games into the world's largest producer of slot machines, died on Tuesday at his home in Palm Desert, Calif. He was 72.

title: COMCAST SELLS 11 PERCENT STAKE IN NEXTEL
description: The Comcast Corporation said yesterday that it had sold its 11 percent stake in Nextel Communications Inc. for $212.7 million. Comcast, the nation's No. 3 cable TV company, said that it had sold the 11.3 million shares "to take advantage of favorable market conditions" but that it "remains excited about Nextel's future prospects." Lehman Brothers and Morgan Stanley & Company bought the Nextel shares for $18.875 each and plan to sell them at a public offering. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, Nextel's stock fell $1.25, to $18.875.

description: A New Jersey parole officer under suspension for his supervision of Darnell Collins, the parolee who went on a killing spree last month, talked yesterday about balancing punishment and compassion when handling convicts and ex-convicts. State officials talking about the same subject spoke mostly about punishment.

description: The Midas International Corporation has begun a review on its national account, with billings estimated at $23 million. The Chicago office of Wells Rich Greene BDDP, which has handled the account for the last 25 years, declined an invitation to participate and resigned.

description: A 50-foot cruise boat capsized in the East River near midtown Manhattan last night, sending at least 38 passengers and crew members into the water, where they clung to the overturned boat or clambered into a life raft before being scooped up by the Coast Guard, the police and other rescuers.

description: The syndicated financial radio talk-show host Sonny Bloch pleaded not guilty yesterday to tax fraud and perjury charges.

description: Hardly a day passes that somewhere in the nation's capital local officials are not wrangling over the city's financial crisis. But today was unusual for the number of people involved.

title: G.O.P. Pushes Query On Idaho Standoff
description: Republican lawmakers intensified their demands today for a Congressional investigation into the Federal Bureau of Investigation's 1992 standoff with a white separatist in Idaho after a veteran agent was suspended as part of the Justice Department's inquiry into whether important internal documents related to the siege were destroyed.

title: Nashville Still Seeks Team
description: At least for now, the agreement between the Devils and the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority puts an end to speculation that the Devils would decamp next season for Nashville, which had been luring the team with a promise of a new state-of-the-art arena and sweeteners such as a $20 million relocation bonus.

title: International Briefs; Ricoh Bids to Buy Rest of Gestetner Shares
description: Ricoh, a leading worldwide office equipment supplier, said yesterday that it would seek to buy the shares outstanding of Gestetner Holdings P.L.C. for about $:115 million, or $182 million. Ricoh already owns or has an option to purchase shares representing 43.95 percent of Gestetner, a worldwide office supply maker and distributor. Gestetner rejected the offer as "opportunistic" but said it would negotiate with Ricoh.

title: U.S. Spells Out Antitrust Inquiry Into Microsoft
description: The Justice Department said today that the Microsoft Corporation might well be violating antitrust laws by including software for its new on-line network in Windows 95, its much-anticipated operating system for personal computers.

title: Briles-Hinton Takes the Lead And Sets Mark
description: A mountain was over their shoulders, a deer was in front of the 12th tee and a 16-year-old invaded the leader board. The 50th United States Women's Open met the wilderness today, and the results were minor gusts, a severe rough, sloping greens and, out of the blue, a course record score of 66.

title: On Long Island, a Mix of Styles and Subjects
description: Long Island's stock of summer exhibitions should improve in about 48 hours. On Sunday, the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton opens "Face Value: American Portraits," an examination of the last 100 years of portraiture, with more than 75 works by artists ranging from William Merritt Chase to Lyle Ashton Harris. In the meantime, the island's art pickings are a little slimmer than in years past, though highly diverse in both form and subject. Roslyn Harbor

title: Decrying Base-Closing Plan as an 'Outrage,' the President Gives a Grudging Go-Ahead
description: President Clinton gave a grudging go-ahead today to closing or consolidating 105 military bases. The shutdowns, a consequence of the end of the cold war, are expected to save billions of Federal dollars but put tens of thousands of people out of work.

title: A Rainbow Coalition In 'Ceiling'
description: SOMETHING usually fizzles when a classical composer tries to tame the wild beasts of pop. Once domesticated, they lose their spirit. An academic self-consciousness and reserve mute their colors and compromise their spontaneity. They become obedient, well-behaved pets that can safely be let loose in a concert hall without upsetting (or exciting) anybody.

title: It May Be Near Wall Street, But Not Shouting Distance
description: Since the days of sailing ships and mercantile princes, lower Manhattan has retained its position as the place where trade deals get done. Companies may rise and fall, but the exchanges go on and on.

title: MEXICAN ECONOMY TO HURT COLGATE-PALMOLIVE EARNINGS
description: The Colgate-Palmolive Company said late yesterday that it expects its second-quarter earnings to be below Wall Street's expectations because of economic conditions in Mexico. The consumer-products company said profits from other operations would not offset the lower profit from Mexico. Colgate-Palmolive, based in New York, said it expects earnings of 95 cents a share for the second quarter. First Call Inc. had reported a consensus earnings prediction of $1.05 a share. For the second quarter of 1994, Colgate-Palmolive reported net income of $142.5 million, or 93 cents a share, on sales of $1.89 billion. Colgate-Palmolive made its projection after the close of trading on the New York Stock Exchange, where its shares closed at $72.125, down 62.5 cents.

title: Long Way From Home And Long Off the Tee
description: She has a cartoon character on her golf bag, a high school prom in her future and her name on a leader board. Grace Park is golf's latest prodigy, at 16, and she drives off the tee better than she drives a car.

title: TAKEOVER RUMORS PUSH CHASE STOCK TO 52-WEEK HIGH
description: The stock price of the Chase Manhattan Corporation shot up yesterday, touching a 52-week high in late trading, as rumors continued that the New York bank would be taken over. Traders and analysts said the talk centered on the Chemical Banking Corporation, a possibility raised in a research report by Ronald I. Mandle, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. Chase Manhattan has been the subject of takeover speculation since April, when Michael F. Price of Heine Securities Inc. took a 6.1 percent stake and said the company should consider selling all or part of itself. Chase's stock traded as high as $55.75 before closing at $54.25, up $3.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: CHRONICLE
description: NINIA BAEHR and GENORA DANCEL are two women who believe they will be married in a legal ceremony one of these days, if a case pending before a Hawaii court goes their way.

description: Year-ago results are restated to reflect change in revenue recognition practice.The company changed its revenue recognization practice prospectively in the fourth quarter of fiscal 1994. title: Dr. George G. Glenner, 67, Dies; Researched Alzheimer's Disease
description: Dr. George G. Glenner, a leading researcher into the molecular structure of the protein amyloid and its relation to Alzheimer's disease, died on Wednesday at his home in San Diego. He was 67.

title: High Proportion of AIDS Cases
description: The number of pediatric AIDS cases in Newark has risen from 59 to 135 over the last six years, while during the same period, the proportion of black children with the disease has increased from 76.2 percent to 83.7 percent, the Black Leadership Commission on AIDS reported yesterday. Blacks constitute 55 percent of Newark's population, yet make up 84 percent of the people with AIDS.

title: Other Issues Overshadow Announcement of Drop in Crime Rate
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Police Commissioner William J. Bratton met with reporters yesterday to announce officially the steepest drop in crime in New York City history. But with the news of the 31 percent drop in murder and the 22 percent drop in robbery in the first half of the year already out since the weekend, the event was dominated by other issues -- including a testy encounter between the Police Commissioner and some Bronx residents on Tuesday and persistent reports of continuing tensions between the Mayor and Mr. Bratton.

title: Colts Give Emtman an Ultimatum
description: The Indianapolis Colts yesterday gave defensive lineman STEVE EMTMAN an ultimatum -- renegotiate or be released. The Colts said they can't afford his $3 million contract. BILL TOBIN, director of operations, said the Colts will give Emtman, the No. 1 pick in the 1992 who has been seriously injured each of his first three seasons, an unconditional release today if no deal is struck. (AP)

title: METRO DIGEST
description: CRUISE BOAT CAPSIZES IN THE EAST RIVER

title: Death Penalty May Be Sought, Second Bombing Suspect Is Told
description: A lawyer for Terry L. Nichols said today that Federal prosecutors had sent him a formal notice that the Government might seek the death penalty for Mr. Nichols on charges that he helped bomb the Federal Building here.

title: With consumers surfing around TV commercials at home, some companies take the ads on the road.
description: AS more consumers "zap" television commercials, advertisers have hit on another strategy to get their messages across: if consumers won't watch commercials at home, why not take the commercials on the road to presumably zap-proof venues?

title: Perils of a Big Name, And Worse, a Big Head
description: Short, bald and grumpy, Michel Blanc looks like an unlikely candidate for suffering the pitfalls of fame. But in "Grosse Fatigue," his enjoyably spiteful comedy about celebrity, Mr. Blanc nonetheless places himself at the center of a flashbulb-popping maelstrom. With an outlook just Woody Allen-ish enough to register the proper chagrin, Mr. Blanc (best known to American audiences for his roles in "Menage" and "Monsieur Hire") casts a chilly eye upon the absurdities of stardom. And if you've ever wondered how Gerard Depardieu manages to make so many films, Mr. Blanc has an interesting answer.

title: Enron Oil & Gas Co. (EOG,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jun 30
Test Scores Penalize Minority Student Athletes; No National Exam
description: To the Editor:

title: Test Scores Penalize Minority Student Athletes; Dump the S.A.T
description: To the Editor:

title: Merck's Drug for Bone Weakness Gets F.D.A. Backing
description: A new drug from Merck & Company for treatment of osteoporosis, or bone deterioration in older people, was recommended yesterday for approval by the Food and Drug Administration. Analysts said final approval of the drug, Fosamax, could come by the end of the year.

title: Bomb Scare at Bank
description: The authorities are searching for a man who used a bomb scare to rob the Provident Savings Bank in Green Brook earlier this week and who also may have tried to rob the Acme Check Cashing Service in Edison.

title: Farm Boy Finding Romance in the Big City
description: The time-honored image of a farm boy, his head filled with romantic dreams, who moves to the big city to make them come true, may have lost much of its currency in the age of grunge rock. But as long as there are cabaret singers like Phillip Officer, who opened a one-month engagement at Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel (54 West 44th Street, Manhattan) on Tuesday evening, that image should remain more than a relic of a more innocent and optimistic time.

title: Stock Market Drifts in Lackluster Trading
description: A day after hitting record levels, the stock market drifted yesterday in lackluster trading.

title: Gored by Bull, U.S. Tourist Dies at Fiesta In Pamplona
description: An American tourist was killed today at the running of the bulls in Pamplona when he was knocked down by one bull, then gored by another.

title: Audit Faults N.A.A.C.P. on Accounting
description: The full audit of 28 top officers of the National Association for the Advancement for Colored People is as thick as the Manhattan telephone book and lists a series of mangled accounting practices.

title: Smith (A.O.) Corp.(AOS,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jun 30
Rookie's Debut Is Radio Only
description: Mets fans itching to watch Jason Isringhausen's pitching debut Monday night in Chicago against the Cubs will have to be satisfied with the radio call.

title: R. E. Goldburg, 78, Connecticut Rabbi
description: Rabbi Robert E. Goldburg, the former spiritual leader of Congregation Mishkan Israel in Hamden, Conn., died on Tuesday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 78 and lived in Manhattan, where he moved from Hamden after retiring in 1982.

title: Sherwin-Williams Co.(SHW,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jun 30
Squatters' Rights vs. City Rights
description: A group of rundown tenements on Manhattan's Lower East Side lived in by squatters for years may well have benefited from their occupation. The squatters have fixed up the city-owned buildings with their own money and sweat, securing them from drug users and criminals. Now the buildings are a vicious battleground.

title: Atmel Corp.(ATML,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Jun 30
Schools and Transit Get Taken for a Ride
description: To the Editor:

title: FEDERAL TAX REFUND TO LIFT THIOKOL '95 EARNINGS
description: The Thiokol Corporation said yesterday that it would get a $65 million Federal tax refund, after an audit of its returns for 1983 to 1985. Thiokol said the refund would increase earnings for its 1995 fiscal year, which ended June 30, by about $44.5 million, or $2.37 a share. The remaining amount will be retained to pay future liabilities. In the 1994 fiscal year, the company had a loss of $3.5 million, or 18 cents a share, including an accounting charge of $63.8 million, or $3.20 a share. Thiokol, based in Ogden, Utah, produces propulsion systems, weapons and other products for the space and military industries. Its stock rose $1.75 yesterday, to $31.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Bosnia's Human Emergency
description: Forty thousand men, women and children, their safety supposedly guaranteed by the United Nations Security Council, are now desperate, helpless victims of the latest Bosnian Serb offensive and the fall of Srebrenica.

title: Southern in Hostile Bid for British Utility
description: The Southern Company began a $1.6 billion hostile takeover bid today for South Western Electricity P.L.C., a British utility.

title: Hudson Valley Crop: Portraits and di Suvero
description: In the Hudson Valley this summer is a range of art, from Minimalist sculptures at Bard College to contemporary Mexican photographs in Purchase to a rambunctious show of portraits at the Hudson River Museum. This is also the summer that the sculptor Mark di Suvero was back at the Storm King Art Center in Mountainville.

title: In New Jersey, Nature in Abstract and a Prison Cell
description: Summer is the traditional down time for the art world, but New Jersey museums are offering some surprisingly intense shows. They include a retrospective of visionary paintings by a reclusive American artist, a multimedia storefront installation on family ties by one of our most impressive Puerto Rican artists and an intergenerational homage to a firebrand political leader whom many people consider a martyr. Montclair

title: Price of School Cuts
description: Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines said that local school districts should be allowed to increase class size to 27 pupils from 25 and to shorten the school day in elementary schools.

title: Fed's No. 2 Is Said to Be Dissatisfied
description: Raising a delicate political question, Alan S. Blinder, the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, has been expressing dissatisfaction with his job to Administration officials, leading the White House to begin looking for a possible successor when his term ends in January, officials said today.

title: Abroad at Home; Weakness As Policy
description: From time to time, over the years since 1945, international security experts have speculated on what the world would be like without American leadership. Now they know.

title: No Headline
description: "I saw neighbors dead, and it made me crazy. The first night the Serbs were in the town, we heard screaming in the streets until morning. They took women away and did bad things to them, and killed men the way you slaughter cattle." HAKA NUKIC, 67, describing the conquest of Srebrenica. [ A8:2. ]

title: France Asks Allied Forces to Help Hold 'Safe Areas'
description: France called on the United States and Britain today to join in military operations to save other United Nations-designated "safe zones" in Bosnia from the fate of Srebrenica, which Bosnian Serb forces overran practically without a fight on Wednesday.

title: Market Place; Archer-Daniels-Midland stock is off, but some see a buy.
description: SHARES of Archer-Daniels-Midland have been pummeled in the last week after disclosures about an unusually broad and aggressive criminal antitrust investigation of the giant grain and soybean processor. And many analysts have been warning of more trouble ahead for the stock.

title: Live, With the King of 40,000 Parties
description: "EVERYBODY knows me," Herb Sherry was saying. "It happens everywhere I go. I'm playing tennis. I'm introduced to this guy. I say my name's Herb Sherry. He says: 'Herb Sherry, the band leader?' "

title: Green Tree Financial Corp.(GNT,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jun 30
Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions that are to close soon: Closing This Weekend "BUTTONS ON BROADWAY," Ambassador Theater, 219 West 49th Street, Manhattan. Red Buttons in a one-man show. Through Sunday. Performances: Today and tomorrow at 8 P.M.; Sunday at 3 P.M. Tickets: $25 to $50. Information: (212) 239-6200.

title: UJB Financial Corp.(UJB,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jun 30
Developer and Creditor Bid for Olympia & York U.S.A.
description: A leading real estate developer and the largest creditor of Olympia & York U.S.A. made an unsolicited bid yesterday to gain control of the troubled real estate concern, whose 14-million-square-foot portfolio includes a number of prime Manhattan properties, including the World Financial Center.

title: J.P. Morgan Earnings Drop 10%
description: J. P. Morgan & Company said yesterday that net income fell 10 percent in the second quarter, as higher trading profits in the period were not enough to offset the benefit of one-time gains in the quarter a year earlier.

title: Nomination Starts Debate On Bigotry
description: A City Council hearing on the reappointment of a controversial Bronx minister to the police Civilian Complaint Review Board erupted into a raucous debate on the nature of bigotry yesterday. Council members angrily argued over which forms of prejudice were worse.

title: Ellis Island Succeeds As Park Restoration
description: To the Editor:

title: Seles Lawyer Appeals Parche Sentence
description: The lawyer for MONICA SELES has appealed the lenient sentence given to the man who stabbed Seles in 1993 and halted the career of tennis' top-ranked player. In his trial in October 1993 and his retrial last April, GUNTER PARCHE, 41, was convicted of causing grievous bodily harm and given a suspended two-year sentence both times. GERHARD STRATE, Seles's lawyer, has appealed the verdict and the sentence, court officials in Hamburg, Germany, said yesterday. The lawyer said Parche should have been tried and convicted on attempted manslaughter charges. (AP)

title: Rabbi Won't Face Charge of Bribery
description: Bribery charges against an Orthodox rabbi in Lakewood, N.J., and two other men were dismissed yesterday in New Jersey Superior Court.

title: The Lens of the Beholder: 60 Years of Photographing the Soviet Empire
description: It would be hard to find anyone who has seen more of this cruel century than Yevgeny Khaldei.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HOSPITALITY FRANCHISE SYSTEMS INC., Parsippany, N.J., said it had signed a definitive agreement to buy Century 21 Real Estate Corp., Irvine, Calif., from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, New York. Terms were not disclosed. PANACO INC., an oil and gas company in Kansas City, Mo., announced it would acquire the Gulf of Mexico properties of Zapata Exploration Co., a unit of Zapata Corp., Houston. Terms were not disclosed.

title: House Panel to Draft Bill Requiring AIDS Tests of Newborns
description: Despite heavy opposition from medical groups and advocates for people with AIDS, leaders of the House Commerce Committee said today that they had agreed to draft bipartisan legislation that would require newborns to be tested for the virus that causes AIDS unless their mothers had been tested in pregnancy.

title: ACCORD IN HOUSE WOULD KILL FUNDS FOR ARTS BY 1997
description: Faced with a freshman-led mutiny, House Republican leaders agreed today to cut off all Federal funding to the National Endowment for the Arts within two years -- a year earlier than they had planned and five years ahead of the Senate's schedule.

title: Hibernia Corp.(HIB,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jun 30
2d Highest Budget Official In Connecticut Resigns
description: Just seven months after becoming the most prominent Democrat in a new Republican administration, Lorraine M. Aronson resigned today as the state's second-ranking budget official to take a high-level post at the University of Connecticut.

title: Decision to Stay in New Jersey Has Players' Approval
description: From New Jersey to Minnesota to western Canada, Devils players were delighted yesterday to hear that the Stanley Cup championship banner will be raised in East Rutherford, N.J.

title: For U.S. Business, a Hard Road to Vietnam
description: Like a great triumphal gateway, two newly painted, giant Coca-Cola bottles greet visitors in bold Vietnamese on either side of the four-lane highway from the airport: "Coke welcomes you to Hanoi."

title: 13-Year-Old Pleads Not Guilty
description: A 13-year-old boy pleaded not guilty in Family Court yesterday to strangling a 3-year-old girl who would not stop crying. Carmen Messano, the Hudson County Prosecutor, said it appeared that the girl, Chantel Cuffee, was sleeping in the boy's room Tuesday night, when the strangling occurred, because the teen-ager's older sister was her baby sitter.

title: Magic Furniture and a Tiny Friend
description: The best reason for children to see "The Indian in the Cupboard" is illustrated by the film itself. It features a scene in which fighting breaks out between the title American Indian and his teeny little cowboy counterpart after they happen to glimpse a violent western movie on television. We hardly needed further proof that viewers, especially young ones, are influenced by what they see. So here's a nice film that has nothing to do with greed, comic books or world domination. Children should be charmed by its fantasy world, and parents will be reasonably entertained.

title: The Guns of Waco and Ruby Ridge
description: There is little doubt that the Federal Government contributed heavily to two of the biggest law enforcement fiascoes in recent memory. One was the disastrous 1993 Federal raid on the Branch Davidian compound at Waco, Tex. The other was the tragic 1992 encounter between the F.B.I. and a band of white separatists at Ruby Ridge, Idaho. It is now equally clear that official investigations into both incidents are themselves flawed. Those in charge of these inquiries must move decisively to prevent any further erosion of credibility.

title: Howard Learning The Ropes As a Jet
description: In 1993 and 1994, Erik Howard and Mike Fox played side by side as the Giants' starting defensive tackles. Howard was a one-time Pro Bowl nose tackle. Fox was a journeyman.

title: Princeton Has a New Head Coach, Again
description: Princeton University yesterday signed LIZ FEELY, who turned around the Colgate program, to a four-year contract -- the second head coach the university has hired in less than a month. After signing a contract on June 22, JULIE PLANK stepped down on June 30.

title: Bill Takes On Health Issue In Small Steps
description: Senators Nancy Landon Kassebaum and Edward M. Kennedy today introduced the first major bipartisan health legislation of this Congress, a bill designed to require insurance companies to cover people with existing medical problems and to enable workers to keep insurance when they leave their jobs.

title: For Once, All Falls In Place For Mets
description: One game cannot erase the miserable first half of the season the Mets endured. But if they are to earn some respect before the summer is over, they have to start somewhere. Maybe last night was that start.

title: Monument Intact, From Mark Morris
description: "L'Allegro, il Penseroso ed il Moderato," the life-affirming communal celebration that Mark Morris choreographed to Handel's oratorio of the same name, had its New York premiere at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in 1989. At that time, one year after it was first produced in Brussels, the work was clearly the best that Mr. Morris had created.

title: Clinton Is Scrambling to Find Way to Help U.N. in Bosnia
description: With its Bosnia policy under fresh assault in Europe and in Congress, the Administration searched feverishly today for ways to salvage as much of the disintegrating United Nations peacekeeping effort as possible, partly for humanitarian reasons but in large measure to avoid sending American troops to assist in a dangerous withdrawal of the peacekeeping forces.

title: He's a Prisoner, the Least of His Worries
description: Jon Voight, a fine actor whose film credits include acclaimed performances in "Midnight Cowboy," "Coming Home" and "Runaway Train," could use a good movie at this stage of his career. "Convict Cowboy," Sunday's Showtime "original movie" out of MGM, isn't it.

title: Commuters Try to Reserve Parking Space
description: While negotiators for the Metro-North Railroad and representatives of 17 unions bargained toward a strike deadline of 12:01 A.M. on Sunday, some commuters were preparing for the worst by trying to reserve parking space in Manhattan lots and garages.

title: Unicom Corp.(UCM,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jun 30
description: b-Net lossc-Included charges of $ 10 million for cost of early retirement program; and $ 34 million for reduction in carrying value of investment in Commonwealth Edison Co.'s uranium-related properties.(Loss)

title: Corrections
description: A theater review on Wednesday about "The Tempest" at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park omitted the name of one composer of the score. He is Carlos Valdez. The review also misspelled the surname of the other composer. He is Dan Moses Schreier.

title: Williams Encourages Airing of Controversy
description: To the Editor:

title: On Voting Rights, Court Faces a Tangled Web
description: Thirty years after President Lyndon B. Johnson signed the Voting Rights Act, in a highly symbolic ceremony in the room in the Capitol where Abraham Lincoln signed the Emancipation Proclamation, the Supreme Court has issued dozens of decisions interpreting this fundamental civil rights law. Yet the law of voting rights remains, to a surprising and unsettling degree, part of the Court's unfinished business.

title: Trial of a Queens Doctor In Botched Abortion Starts
description: Fearing that he could lose his medical license, a Queens doctor intentionally misled paramedics who arrived at his office two years ago to treat a 33-year-old woman who bled to death after an abortion, prosecutors said yesterday as they began their murder case against the doctor.

title: Union Camp Corp.(UCC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jun 30
description: b-Included a gain of 14 cents a share from nonrecurring items, for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Argentina Is Tough Test For U.S.
description: Hoping to show that its conquest of the United States Cup last month was not simply a fluke, the United States national team will try to secure a spot in the quarterfinals of the America Cup Friday night when it takes on the tournament favorite, Argentina, in the final match of the first round.

title: Report Urges New Steps to Protect Blood Supply
description: New steps are needed to prevent the disastrous spread of another dangerous infectious agent like H.I.V. because the ability of the nation's blood banking and public health systems to identify and guard against unknown microbes is weak, according to a report prepared for the Federal Government.

title: The Panic And Perils Of Making Movies
description: "Living in Oblivion" was shown as part of this year's New Directors/ New Films series. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 17. The film opens today in Manhattan.

title: Burr-Brown Corp.(BBRC,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding are restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in May 1995.

title: Library Discovery Turns A Legend Into Reality
description: The story has assumed almost mythic proportions among law professors and students: how in 1957, the eminent Oxford legal scholar H. L. A. Hart threatened to withdraw his article on law and morality from the Harvard Law Review unless the editors stopped cutting swaths from it. But the story was unproven.

title: Boy Held in Rape Is Suspect in 9 Robberies
description: A 15-year-old Brooklyn boy has been arrested and charged with the rape and robbery of a 20-year-old woman and two other armed robberies in central Brooklyn on Wednesday, and the police said they were investigating whether he was connected to seven other muggings in the area over the last few weeks.

title: Amsco International Inc.(ASZ,N) reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: b-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $ 62,607,000, or $ 2.02 a share, in the quarter and $ 66,055,000, or $ 2.13 a share, in the 6 months.Year-ago quarter's loss from continuing operations of $ 1,546,000, or 5 cents a share, and 6 months' income from continuing operations of $ 2,583,000, or 8 cents a share, both included restructuring charges of 6 cents a share and a 10-cent-a-share product upgrade charge.(Loss)

title: Art in Greener Pastures, Outside New York
description: WASN'T it Henry James who wrote about the special pleasure of visiting museums outside the big city? The surroundings are agreeable, the distractions fewer. There is the possibility of discovery. James was talking about Paris, but the same applies to New York. This summer the discoveries are out there in places like Montclair, N.J., and Yonkers.

title: Muslims Tell of Atrocities in Bosnian Town
description: Thousands of stunned Muslim refugees streamed into this town in northern Bosnia today, telling of bodies left hanging from trees and littering the street after the Bosnian Serb conquest of the "safe area" of Srebrenica.

title: Test Scores Penalize Minority Student Athletes
description: To the Editor:

title: Louise Reinhardt Smith, 91, Patron of the Modern, Is Dead
description: Louise Reinhardt Smith, a discerning collector of modern art and a prized supporter of the Museum of Modern Art since 1957, died on Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 91.

title: Godtfred K. Christiansen, 75; Covered the World With Lego
description: Godtfred Kirk Christiansen, a Danish executive who made Lego plastic building-block sets into children's favorites in many countries around the world, died on Thursday in his house in Billund, Denmark. He was 75.

title: Giants Sign Running Back
description: The Giants have signed another draft pick, running back Charles Way, according to his agent, Sean Holley. Though the Giants have not officially announced the signing, the addition of Way, a sixth-round pick, means the team has signed two of its nine picks and should have most if not all of them signed by the end of next week -- just in time for the beginning of training camp on July 23.

title: Free Programs And Favorite Agencies Fall In Budget Cuts
description: "Woooh, woooh, we do not want to know about it," scolded a derisive Democrat in ghostly tones as the House Republican majority leadership found itself uncomfortably arguing, amid a long day of bare-knuckled budget cutting, against the cost-free use of volunteer bird-watchers in a nature census.

title: Don't 'Throw Until You Die'
description: Two decades after Commodore Matthew Perry forced Japan out of isolation in 1854, the Japanese started playing baseball. This year Hideo Nomo, the 26-year-old imported pitching star of the Los Angeles Dodgers, has emerged to remind Americans that Japan's longstanding baseball pretensions must be taken seriously. By instantly becoming one of the best pitchers in the National League, Nomo has enlivened and internationalized the game in a sullen year. The secret of his success may be instructive.

title: State Seeks Casino Offers With Hefty Guarantees
description: Taking an important step toward opening a casino in Bridgeport, Gov. John G. Rowland issued a formal call today for proposals from developers that required guarantees to the state of hundreds of millions of dollars in revenue.

title: Outside Counsel May Yet Look at Gingrich
description: The House ethics committee may yet seek an outside counsel to help it look into complaints against Speaker Newt Gingrich, the committee's chairwoman says.

title: Columbia-Presbyterian Strives for Quality Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A corporate symbol in Business Day yesterday, in a picture grouping with an article about growing sales of mass-autographed sports merchandise, was published in error. It was the logo of Major League Baseball Properties Inc., not that of the Major League Baseball Players Association; the Players Association, not Major League Baseball, receives a $2.50 licensing fee on the sale of each autographed ball.

title: Thomas G. Aylesworth, 67, Writer of More Than 100 Books
description: Thomas Gibbons Aylesworth, the author of more than 100 books written mostly for children and young adults, died on Thursday at his home in Stamford, Conn. He was 67.

title: Jets' Anderson Relishes His Starting Designation
description: Two years ago, the Jets made a draft-day deal for Johnny Johnson that brought them good news and bad news.

title: CRAY COMPUTER HAS DECIDED TO SELL ALL OF ITS ASSETS
description: The board of the Cray Computer Corporation gave up hope of resuscitating the company, a supercomputer maker, and voted yesterday to sell its assets to pay creditors. The company, which was founded by Seymour Cray, the supercomputer guru, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on March 24. At that time, it dismissed its entire staff of about 300 and ceased operations. The company, based in Colorado Springs, said yesterday that since the filing its officers had tried to line up financing to resume operations and had determined Cray Computer could not be saved.

title: No Air Accord In Tokyo Talks
description: Talks between Japan and the United States over an aviation dispute ended here today without agreement, said Daniel Tarullo, the assistant secretary for economic and business affairs at the State Department.

title: Chip Stocks Fall but Recover
description: Shares of semiconductor makers and related companies declined yesterday but then rebounded somewhat after investors reassessed a drop in the computer chip industry's key gauge of demand.

title: Devils Say the Escape Clause Is Essential
description: The owner of the Devils said yesterday that a provision in the tentative lease agreement reached Thursday that would trigger an escape clause if the Yankees moved to New Jersey was essential to his business future.

title: Blues Add Courtnall to Shopping Cart
description: The St. Louis Blues continued their July spending spree yesterday, signing the unrestricted free agent left wing GEOFF COURTNALL to a three-year, $6.6 million deal. Earlier in the week, the Blues signed two other unrestricted free agents, goalie GRANT FUHR and right wing BRIAN NOONAN. On draft day last Saturday, they signed Buffalo center DALE HAWERCHUK.

title: County Clerk Convicted in Graft
description: Michael S. Keating, the Camden County Clerk, was convicted yesterday of taking $173,000 in bribes over 15 years from two printers of election ballots. Mr. Keating, 55, faces a minimum of seven years in prison when he is sentenced in September. JOE SHARKEY

title: Hitchcock Is a Work In Progress For Yanks
description: The Yankees ostensibly brought in a new pitching coach, Nardi Contreras, to work with their young starters. Coach Contreras, meet Sterling Hitchcock.

title: Retired Police Chief Is Killed in a Cemetery Holdup
description: A retired police chief from Hanover, N.J., was shot to death yesterday in a Newark cemetery while trying to help an elderly friend who had been set upon by robbers, the police said..

title: Tactics Used Against Squatters Anger Neighbors and Stores
description: Art Guerra, a painter, supports his art with the business he runs on the Lower East Side, Guerra Paint, a supply store frequented by other artists and interior decorators. But for the last several weeks, business has been seriously down, he said -- and not because of a market slowdown, rising costs or any of the other ordinary economic hazards.

title: When Machines, Not Humans, Are the Kings of a Concert
description: Ever since the advent of machines and computers, humans have been wrestling with the problem of how much technology they should allow to impinge on their daily lives. To avoid a Frankenstein situation -- that of a powerful, self-operating invention run amok -- society has embraced a future that incorporates the Internet and interactive technology.

title: U.S. Weighs a Response To French Call on Bosnia
description: President Clinton's senior national security advisers huddled for more than two hours today but failed to produce a response to the French challenge to the United States and Britain to increase their involvement in the faltering United Nations peacekeeping effort in Bosnia.

title: High Marks on Environment
description: State Senator Gordon A. MacInnes, Democrat of Denville, was the only member of the Legislature to be awarded a perfect score on environmental and consumer issues by the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group Citizen Lobby, the organization announced yesterday. In the Assembly, the highest scorers were Robert G. Smith, Democrat of Piscataway (88 percent), and Maureen Ogden, Republican of Millburn (77 percent), while Senator William E. Schluter (75 percent), Republican of Pennington, scored next-highest in the Senate.

title: International Briefs; Big Belgian Bank Seeks Credit Lyonnais Unit
description: Generale de Banque S.A., Belgium's biggest bank, said yesterday that it was close to an agreement to buy Credit Lyonnais Bank Nederland N.V. Generale de Banque said it was the only bidder for the Dutch unit of the French state-owned bank Credit Lyonnais. Credit Lyonnais wants to sell its Dutch unit to reduce debt as part of an initiative aimed at European Union approval for a Government bailout of 130 billion French francs ($27 billion).

title: CHRONICLE
description: Earth is starting to feel a lot more normal for Dr. NORMAN E. THAGARD, the American astronaut who returned a week ago from Russia's Mir space station after spending 115 days in orbit, a United States record.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Mexican Bailout Defended Amid G.O.P. Criticism
description: Top Treasury officials today defended the American-led bailout of Mexico last winter as a success, but Congressional Republicans criticized the Administration for lending more money to Mexico this summer.

title: Morris Chase, 90, Welfare Official and Advocate for the Homeless
description: Morris Chase, a former welfare official who supervised New York City's efforts to deal with the homeless in the 1960's, took his life in San Francisco on Wednesday. He was 90.

title: Bridge
description: One of the most entertaining bridge books published in recent years is "The Kings' Tales," by Phillip and Robert King. It is available for $19.50 including mailing from The Bridge World, 39 West 94th Street, New York 10025.

title: President Is Said to Endorse Most of Affirmative Action
description: President Clinton briefed leaders of civil rights groups today on his five-month review of affirmative action programs, and people who attended the meeting predicted that Mr. Clinton would vigorously defend most such programs in a speech next week.

title: Revivim Journal; Bedouins' Fate: No Room for Tents in the Desert
description: Ali Lawaji could not have looked more late 20th century as he drove along the desert sands, dropping a hand from the wheel to answer his cellular phone and talk about how his children need a computer to help them in their studies.

title: 13-Year-Old Pleads Not Guilty
description: A 13-year-old boy pleaded not guilty in Family Court yesterday to strangling a 3-year-old girl who would not stop crying. Carmen Messano, the Hudson County Prosecutor, said it appeared that the girl, Chantel Cuffee, was sleeping in the boy's room Tuesday night, when the strangling occurred, because the teen-ager's older sister was her baby sitter.

title: Rail Talks Incite Debate On Strike Law
description: Negotiations between the Metro-North Railroad and 17 of its unions intensified yesterday, but officials on both sides of the dispute said they were far from a contract settlement. The unions are threatening to strike as early as 12:01 tomorrow morning.

title: After Years Of Fighting Big Losses, A Retreat
description: When New York Newsday's final issue rolls off the press tomorrow, it will have lasted 10 years, 3 months and 1 day. Begun with expectations that it would outlive at least one of its competitors, it will be survived by the same three newspapers that it squared off against on Day 1: The Daily News, The New York Post and The New York Times.

title: Violence Grows Against Ranchers
description: To the Editor:

title: Echoes of the Big Bang; The Bomb Imposed Its Own Peace
description: Just before dawn on July 16, 1945 50 years ago tomorrow -- the first atomic bomb exploded on a tower in the high desert north of Alamogordo, N.M., at a place code-named Trinity. "A new thing had just been born," said the physicist I. I. Rabi, who was there, "a new control." Released nuclear energy, Dr. Rabi thought, was a new power "which man had acquired over nature," but he also believed that it would result in a "new understanding of man."

title: High Proportion of AIDS Cases
description: The number of pediatric AIDS cases in Newark has risen from 59 to 135 over the last six years, while during the same period, the proportion of black children with the disease has increased from 76.2 percent to 83.7 percent, the Black Leadership Commission on AIDS reported yesterday. Blacks constitute 55 percent of Newark's population, yet make up 84 percent of the people with AIDS.

title: Seles, Seeding Uncertain, Enters U.S. Open
description: MONICA SELES yesterday entered the United States Open, her first Grand Slam event since she was stabbed in the back in 1993. "We couldn't be happier," PAGE CROSLAND, director of communications for the United States Tennis Association, said. "We were anticipating it. We've been waiting for her and we're delighted."

title: Ringo Starr's Fans Look Back and Sing
description: As the popular rock music of decades past turns into nostalgia, its vision, passion and ability to inspire change often wear away. What's left are just songs, stripped of meaning but full of familiarity. On Thursday night at Radio City Music Hall, the former Beatles drummer Ringo Starr gathered a mixed bag of rockers from the 1960's and 70's to perform together as Ringo Starr and His All-Starr Band.

title: MAPINFO STOCK IS DOWN ON LOWER GROWTH EXPECTATIONS
description: Shares of the Mapinfo Corporation plunged 34 percent yesterday after the company said it did not meet its growth expectations and that third-quarter profit would be well below Wall Street projections. Mapinfo said it would post net income of 13 cents or 14 cents a share on revenues of $9.9 million to $10 million for the quarter that ended on June 30. Wall Street had expected earnings of 22 cents a share for the company, a maker of desktop mapping software, based in Troy, N.Y., according to a survey of analysts by First Call Inc. The company earned $857,000, or 15 cents a share, on revenues of $8 million in the third quarter a year earlier. Mapinfo's stock tumbled $11.875, to $22.375, in Nasdaq trading.

title: GAMBRO MAKES OFFER OF $170 MILLION FOR REN
description: Gambro A.B. said yesterday that it had offered $18 a share, or $170 million, to buy the rest of the REN Corporation-U.S.A. of Nashville, a provider of kidney dialysis services. Gambro, a Swedish medical technology company, said the offer would be carried out through its United States subsidiary, COBE Laboratories Inc., which already holds about 53 percent of REN's common stock. REN's stock soared $3.375, to $19.125 a share, in Nasdaq trading of 2.7 million shares. REN's board has established a special committee to evaluate the terms of the offer and to make recommendations, Gambro said.

title: Delicate Matters of Balance
description: The instruments, even the hall, must match if Baroque performance is to go well these days. And indeed, Catherine Mackintosh, Maggie Cole and the Frick Collection's small, rounded space fit together as well as they possibly could. Miss Mackintosh played the Baroque violin and briefly the viola d'amore on Wednesday. Miss Cole was the harpsichordist. The hall, overflowing with listeners, resonated at just about the right rate.

title: Golfers Endure Delay and Darkness
description: The gallery rooted for one and a half golfers today. Dawn Coe-Jones, who says her nightmare is giving birth in a bunker, lit up the United States Women's Open here in maternity clothes.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK NEWSDAY TO STOP PUBLISHING New York Newsday, a bold experiment by a suburban newspaper to break into the largest and most competitive city market with a new type of tabloid, will publish its last issue tomorrow, its publishers said. The paper, which emerged in the economic boom of the mid-1980's, was the victim of corporate pressures for profits and a market that changed sharply over the last decade. [ Page 1. ] When its final issue rolls off the press, New York Newsday will have lasted 10 years, 3 months and 1 day. Begun with expectations that it would outlive at least one of its competitors, it will be survived by the same three newspapers that it squared off against on Day 1: The Daily News, The New York Post and The New York Times. [ 26. ]

title: Buchanan Challenges Gramm to Debate
description: Raw Presidential politics intruded on the Republican Party's hopes for a harmonious summer meeting here today as Patrick J. Buchanan challenged Senator Phil Gramm of Texas to a televised debate over who is the true conservative seeking the party's nomination.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Colbert Sets Record

title: NOVADIGM SHARES RISE ON FIRST DAY OF TRADING
description: The shares of Novadigm Inc. rose yesterday in their first day of Nasdaq trading as investors showed confidence in the future of large computer systems and the software that drives them. Novadigm originally filed to sell 2.5 million shares at $9 to $11 each, but the issue was finally priced at $15 a share. The company raised $37.5 million in the offering. Novadigm's shares closed at $23.125 as almost 3.4 million shares were traded. The company, based in Saddle Brook, N.J., develops and sells software that helps manage large computer systems. The company, incorporated in February 1992, has yet to show a profit. Yesterday's offering represents a 15 percent stake in Novadigm.

title: Murder of Bronx Teacher Leaves Police Puzzled
description: At first the shooting death of Barbara Eastmond, a remedial reading teacher at Public School 14 in Throgs Neck, appeared to be the result of a botched robbery.

title: Mayor Balks On Increase In Class Size
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that the Board of Education had to work harder at cutting its bureaucracy and should look for volunteer help before permitting a rise in class sizes or shortening the school day.

title: New Zealand Seeks Causes of Suicides by Young
description: From a distance, at least, a teen-ager raised in New Zealand would seem to be growing up in paradise.

title: Torrid Heat, Intensifying, Grips Region
description: The scourge of heat that killed at least 15 people and thousands of cattle in the Midwest descended upon the New York area yesterday, bringing a high-misery combination of near-record temperatures in the mid-90's and the heavy wetness of a tropical rain forest.

title: WINDOWS 95 SENT TO MANUFACTURING PLANTS
description: The Microsoft Corporation yesterday sent the final version of its long-awaited Windows 95 operating system to its manufacturing plants. Microsoft, based in Redmond, Wash., said Windows 95 would be on retail shelves and pre-installed on personal computers on Aug. 24. Windows 95 is the latest version of the Windows operating system, the fundamental program that controls the basic functions of about 60 million personal computers worldwide. Microsoft, the world's biggest personal computer software company, will ship about 30 million copies of Windows 95 through the end of 1995, according to Dataquest Inc., a market researcher. Microsoft's stock jumped $3.50 a share yesterday, to $103.625 on the Nasdaq, a new 52-week high.

title: Missing in Cyprus
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Chief Keeps Promise To Visit War-Torn Africa
description: For the last several days, as the news from Bosnia has grown more grim, Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali has kept his promise to visit three African countries tormented by civil wars that have killed more than a million people and scattered hundreds of thousands of refugees.

title: United States Gives Up Nothing In a Stunning Soccer Victory
description: In a stunning upset at the America Cup tournament, the United States national team achieved one of its biggest international victories tonight by crushing Argentina, 3-0, and advancing to the quarterfinal round.

title: Shore Revelers Under 21, Beware
description: Quaffing a cold one to beat the heat at the seashore is not a good idea if you are under 21, Attorney General Poritz warned yesterday in a visit to the Boardwalk. She said the State Police and agents from the Alcoholic Beverage Control and her office are cracking down on under-age drinking during the summer, with a special emphasis on Shore areas.

title: Boeing's Early Retirement Costs Will Trim Profits for 2d Quarter
description: The Boeing Company said today that it would take a pretax charge of $600 million for the second quarter because 9,500 employees had accepted early retirement packages.

title: 10-Year Extension for Cincinnati's Coach
description: BOB HUGGINS, who passed up a possible National Basketball Association coaching job with Miami to remain at the University of Cincinnati, has signed a 10-year contract extension. The extension grants Huggins more than $700,000 annually in salary and incentives and includes an annuity, The Cincinnati Enquirer reported yesterday. In six years, Huggins's teams at Cincinnati are 138-58. The Bearcats have gone to the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament each of the last four years. In 14 years as a head coach, Huggins is 306-130. (AP)

title: Parolee Is Arrested for a Rape In Upper East Side Apartment
description: A 24-year-old Manhattan man paroled less than a month ago from a Federal penitentiary was arrested yesterday at his mother's apartment on the Lower East Side and accused of raping a young woman Wednesday night in her penthouse apartment off Fifth Avenue.

title: Business Digest
description: Treasury Bonds Fall On Solid Retail Sales Treasury prices ended lower after a Government report showed surprising strength in consumer spending, shaking the market's view of a slowing economy. The report cast doubt on the prospects for another cut in short-term interest rates.

title: Reflecting on Vietnam Ties, Many Agree That It's Time
description: A generation ago, when the Vietnam War was driving a wedge through America, Marco Scolari, a union concrete worker and World War II veteran, could scarcely bring himself to speak to any man who had avoided military service. Back then, it seemed that passions over Vietnam might never cool, on either side.

title: Bomb Scare at Bank
description: The authorities are searching for a man who used a bomb scare to rob the Provident Savings Bank in Green Brook earlier this week and who also may have tried to rob the Acme Check Cashing Service in Edison.

title: Prosecutor of Susan Smith Offers a Small Compromise
description: As the jury selection process dragged on today, the prosecutor in the Susan Smith murder trial said he would be willing to let the presiding judge determine her fate if she pleaded guilty to drowning her two sons.

title: Indian Music and Dance
description: A program of Indian music and dance is to be presented by Ananda Shankar and his company tomorrow at 5 P.M. at Colden Center, Queens College, Kissena Boulevard and the Long Island Expressway, Flushing. Mr. Shankar is the son of Uday and Amala Shankar, the dancers, and the nephew of Ravi Shankar, the sitarist. The program, which features the dance-drama "Mrignayani," is being produced by the Bengali Association of North America and the Nav Nirmaan Foundation, which helps South Asians living in the United States.

title: Decade-Old New York Newsday To Cease Publishing Tomorrow
description: New York Newsday, a suburban newspaper's bold experiment in breaking into the largest and most competitive city market with a new type of tabloid, will publish its last issue tomorrow, its publishers said yesterday.

title: Subway Saviors
description: New York City's Transit Authority did a remarkable job cleaning up the mess caused by a huge water main break near Times Square last Sunday. A crew of close to 1,000 transit workers had the trains running on the West Side IRT line by the beginning of Monday morning's rush hour -- barely 24 hours after the tracks were completely submerged in water and electric circuits were covered in muck. In a city whose citizens are often frustrated by the minor annoyances of everyday urban life, this was a welcome reminder that New York is capable of doing the big things well.

title: Reporting on U.N. Offers Skewed Picture
description: To the Editor:

title: Journal; Such Stuff as Dreams
description: The moon hanging right over the stage wasn't quite full. Not everything can be perfect. But for a vision of ecstasy in New York City, it would be hard to top the scene in Central Park last Sunday night as 1,900 people watched "The Tempest."

title: Musician's Avant-Garde Soul
description: Last year Warner Brothers Records did something surprising: they recorded and released "Ancient Ritual," by Sonny Simmons, a West Coast avant-garde alto saxophonist. Mr. Simmons was somewhat obscure even at the height of his fame in the 1960's, and the album seemed an odd choice given the prevailing emphasis on classicism in the jazz.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5 BOSNIAN SERBS MOVE ON ZEPA Ignoring international condemnation and Western threats of retaliation, Bosnian Serb forces began an attack on the Muslim enclave of Zepa in eastern Bosnia. 1 Terrorized Bosnian Muslims overwhelmed aid workers in Tuzla. 4

title: Chaos Looms as Rwandans Refuse to Go Home
description: A year after an exodus of a million Rwandans flooded the plains around Goma, more than 720,000 Hutu refugees remain in camps in the area, many of them afraid to return, others rearming and preparing for a military offensive against the Tutsi-led Government in Rwanda.

title: Federal Chill Is Felt By Those in the Arts
description: For some time now, arts groups around the country have been bracing for big cuts in Federal spending on the arts. But few were prepared for Thursday's move by Republicans in the House of Representatives to shut down the national arts and humanities endowments altogether within the next two years.

title: Intuit Signs 19 Deals for Home-Banking Software
description: Intuit Inc. announced yesterday that 19 financial institutions, including many of the nation's largest banks, credit card companies and brokerage firms, would use its popular Quicken software for home banking services beginning this fall.

title: Mitchell Reported Returning to Japan
description: KEVIN MITCHELL will return to Japan next week after a controversial two-month hiatus, according to a news report in Tokyo. Mitchell, a former National League most valuable player and the highest-paid player ever in Japan at about $4 million a year, left the Fukuoka Daiei Hawks for the United States in May for treatment of a knee injury. Hawks officials had disputed the seriousness of the injury. (AP)

title: Newspapers to Merge
description: The Home News of East Brunswick will merge with the News Tribune of Woodbridge to form one newspaper serving the central New Jersey market, parent companies of the two papers announced yesterday. New Jersey Press Inc., which also owns The Asbury Park Press, acquired the News Tribune from the Bergen Record Corporation, owner of The Record in Hackensack.

title: Beliefs; Why the liberal agenda might one day include the battle over euthanasia and assisted suicide.
description: Are euthanasia and assisted suicide about to become part of the liberal agenda? That question is raised by the case of George Delury, a Manhattan man charged with second-degree manslaughter after he willingly acknowledged helping his wife, who was incapacitated mentally and physically from multiple sclerosis, kill herself.

title: Technology Issues Move Up As Some Other Sectors Slip
description: Technology stocks held up yesterday as many other widely followed issues posted losses. The Nasdaq composite index, laden with technology issues, ended higher, while the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined.

title: Senator Threatens Fight on Floor to Press Demand for Public Hearing on Packwood
description: Senator Barbara Boxer, the California Democrat who has led the crusade for public hearings into accusations of sexual and official misconduct against Senator Bob Packwood, threatened today to force a floor vote on the matter unless the Ethics Committee votes within one week to hold such hearings.

title: Billion-Dollar Bet on New Casino
description: Casino industry giants Mirage Resorts and Circus Circus laid down a billion dollars yesterday on a new 4,000-room casino hotel complex. The project, on a 178-acre site in the marina district, will consist of twin 31-story hotel towers and a 115,000-square-foot-casino, said the chairman of Mirage, Steve Wynn, who sold the Golden Nugget casino here in 1987 and vowed never to return because of what he considered overzealous regulation. Mr. Wynn said restrictions lured him back, The Associated Press reported. Ground breaking for the project - which is to generate 14,000 jobs - could come early next year.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on July 10, in the "Fine Print" series about legislation, described the drafting of a law on taxing Americans who become citizens of other countries.

title: A 20-Hit Outburst? Who Are These Mets?
description: It's time for someone to launch an investigation. Call the F.B.I. Call the National Guard. Heck, call Steven Seagal. Somebody has kidnapped the Mets.

title: International Briefs; Study Raises Value Of Bank in Austria
description: J. P. Morgan & Company said yesterday that the Austrian Government's 70 percent voting stake in Creditanstalt-Bankverein was worth as much as 55 percent more than its current market price. The study, commissioned by the Austrian Finance Ministry, puts the value of the 20 million common shares owned by the Republic of Austria at 17.5 billion to 18.7 billion schillings ($1.75 billion to $1.87 billion).

title: New Spokeswoman for Whitman
description: Shaking up her communications staff 18 months into her administration, Governor Whitman named a new press secretary: Becky Taylor, until yesterday the public affairs director for Attonrey General Deborah T. Poritz. Rita Manno, a former reporter who joined the Whitman staff at the start of the Governor's term in 1994, was asked to step aside and has not yet decided whether to accept other posts offered to her, aides said. Ms. Taylor's new job pays $84,500, the same as her old one.

title: Reporting on U.S. Officers Skewed Picture
description: To the Editor:

title: State to Retain Bond Rating
description: A leading bond-rating agency flashed approval of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's recently passed $16 billion budget yesterday. Standard & Poor's said that New Jersey will retain its double-A plus bond rating, the second-highest grade it gives, The Associated Press reported. The agency said it believed the budget, bolstered by the $500 million state surplus, can withstand potential cuts in Federal aid, the posibility that Governor Whitman's revenue projections are too high and a dip in revenue from he income tax cut. Bond ratings help determine interest rates on state borrowing.

title: McVeigh Is Told to Give Writing Sample
description: Timothy J. McVeigh, the former Army sergeant accused of blowing up the Federal Building here, has been ordered to appear before a grand jury on Tuesday to give samples of his handwriting, his lawyer said today.

title: BC TELECOM IS PLANNING TO ELIMINATE 2,000 JOBS
description: BC Telecom Inc. said yesterday that it planned to eliminate 2,000 jobs by the end of 1996 to reduce its operating costs by $100 million Canadian, or $73.4 million United States. The job cuts will shrink the Canadian telecommunications company's 14,500-member work force by nearly 14 percent. BC Telecom said it had discussed the plan with representatives of the Telecommunications Workers Union, which represents about 84 percent of its workers. The cuts will be made through early retirement, voluntary resignations and, if needed, layoffs.

title: Why I Don't Need Toll Booth Operators
description: To the Editor:

title: Prices of Treasuries Retreat On Strong Retail Spending
description: Treasury prices ended lower yesterday after a Government report showed surprising strength in consumer spending. The report shook the market's view of a slowing economy and cast doubt on the prospects for another cut in short-term interest rates.

title: Old Football Injuries and Arthritis Hobbled Simpson, Doctor Testifies
description: A doctor who examined O. J. Simpson twice in the days after Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald L. Goldman were killed testified today that although Mr. Simpson had the "physique of Tarzan," a "whole array of the typical post-N.F.L. injury syndromes" and two kinds of arthritis left him slow of foot, even hobbling.

title: Rutgers Pays Top Dollar for New Coach
description: Rutgers University yesterday hired C. Vivian Stringer as its new women's basketball coach, paying her more than the men's basketball and football coaches and making her perhaps the highest-paid coach in her field.

title: Guilty Plea in Tape Copying
description: A man who mass-produced bootlegged videotapes of hit movies like "Jurassic Park," "The Lion King" and "The Flintstones" in the basement of a home in Nutley pleaded guilty in Federal District Court yesterday to felony copy infringement. The authorities said Nedal Yousef Rasheed made more than 1,000 illegal videotapes a day and earned more than $5,000 a month selling them on the streets of Newark and New York. He agreed to turn in the tapes along with the 52 videocassette recorders he used to make the illegal copies. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Can Alternative Medicine Heal? Trials Will Tell; Endangered Habitats
description: To the Editor:

title: Dance Team: 1 Spunky, 1 Stubborn, Both Artists
description: Marge and Gower Champion epitomized the all-American dance team in their Hollywood musicals and television appearances in the 1950's. Their courtships on film showed them as healthy and unneurotic, often as a stage couple. Total pros and good sports, they could hold their own when Jack Benny popped up in tights to learn ballet from them in a hilarious television skit.

title: Graf Investigated Over German Taxes
description: Lawyers for the Wimbledon champion, STEFFI GRAF, said yesterday that investigators were ignorant of her tax situation, and the world's top-ranked woman player said she trusted her father's management of her financial affairs. Graf, and her father, PETER GRAF, are suspected of tax evasion, German newspapers reported this week. Authorities confirm that investigators searched the Graf family villa in Bruhl on May 23 and seized documents.

title: Slippery Going On the Trapeze
description: The hot weather made life high above the circus crowds even more treacherous than usual.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the growing use of filmless electronic cameras misspelled the surname of a photographer with The Associated Press who uses one. He is David Longstreath.

title: Can Alternative Medicine Heal? Trials Will Tell; Smithsonian Science
description: To the Editor:

title: SERB FORCES SHELL U.N. PEACEKEEPERS AT 2d 'SAFE' AREA
description: Ignoring international condemnation and Western threats of retaliation, Bosnian Serb forces began an attack on another Muslim enclave in eastern Bosnia today, hours after they completed the "ethnic cleansing" of a nearby Muslim area overrun on Wednesday.

title: Mr. Arafat's Governance
description: Yasir Arafat as tough-minded political boss cracking down on Palestinian terrorists seems an incongruous image, but that roughly describes the latest step in his shift from Israel's enemy to its partner in peace. The chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization is now embarked on the administration of Gaza and Jericho, and he has made progress in establishing civil authority.

title: Data Suggest Turnaround For Economy
description: Fresh Government figures today lent strong support to the notion that the slow economy of recent months is heading for better times, not a recession.

title: WICOR TO PURCHASE HYPRO FOR ABOUT $58 MILLION
description: Wicor Inc., a Milwaukee-based holding company, said yesterday that it would buy the Hypro Corporation for about $58 million. Hypro, based in New Brighton, Minn., is a privately held manufacturer of pumps for the agricultural, high-pressure cleaning, marine, industrial and fire-protection markets. It had 1994 sales of $41 million. Hypro's president and chief executive, Ted Dudley, will continue in his position, and Hypro's current management team will remain in place. Wicor, based in Milwaukee, has subsidiaries that sell natural gas and manufacture pumps and water-processing equipment.

title: Those Few Cents Give Us Clout in the World
description: To the Editor:

title: Terrorized Human Tide Overwhelms Relief Camp
description: Terrorized Muslims by the tens of thousands overwhelmed aid workers in an ill-prepared emergency camp here today, part of a swelling human tide propelled by the continuing Bosnian Serb drive across eastern Bosnia.

title: A Quiet Evening River Cruise Became a Terrifying Adventure
description: The printed invitations promised a relaxing river cruise, a quiet night on the water under the city's shimmering lights. And it began just that way.

title: For Elderly and the Outcast, There's No Place Like This Home
description: RITA ROSS is sitting pretty. In fact, the 74-year-old woman, who has spent her whole life within three blocks of her West 35th Street apartment, thinks everything has improved greatly since the mental patients and the homeless people moved into the tenement she had clung to since she became a bride during World War II.

title: Frustrated Croats Are Openly Preparing a Major Assault on a Serbian Enclave
description: As the United Nations peacekeeping mission in Bosnia reels from fresh attacks by rebel Serbs, the Government of Croatia is planning to open a major new front in the Balkan war.

title: Sports of The Times; Heroes, Icons and Monuments
description: EARLIER this week, a small group of amateur athletics officials gathered in Manhattan to celebrate a monumental moment in track and field as the New York Athletic Club became the official home of the Jesse Owens International Trophy.

title: Speculation Rises About the State of Yeltsin's Health
description: Aides to President Boris N. Yeltsin, who was hospitalized on Tuesday with acute chest pain, said today that he had canceled a trip to Norway and all engagements until Monday, July 24, prompting renewed speculation about the state of his health.

title: After Blunt Notice, Newsroom Is in Shock at a Wake for Itself
description: "I don't know what to say," said Murray Kempton, surely for the only time in his decades of newspapering. "I'm at a loss for words."

title: Independence Creates Niche in Health Care
description: In the pharmaceutical industry, where the battle cry has been consolidate or die, one niche player is prospering by avoiding strategic entanglements.

title: TYSON TO ACQUIRE CHICKEN OPERATIONS OF CARGILL
description: Tyson Foods Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire certain chicken-processing operations from the Minneapolis-based Cargill Inc. Tyson said that while the terms of the transaction were not being disclosed, they included an exchange of Tyson's swine processing plant in Marshall, Mo., and an undisclosed amount of cash for Cargill's operations. Tyson will be acquiring Cargill's domestic broiler operations, which include five processing plants in Georgia and Florida. Also included are feed mills and hatcheries for farmers in those areas that grow chickens under contract for Cargill. Cargill, which is closely held, is a grain and commodity-processing concern.

title: And Then He Kissed Her . . . Gross!; Tresses Curled and Outfits Modeled, Girls Go Where the Boys Are
description: Gymnastics class is usually a busy time for the girls in Tamarack and Strongheart. There are girls flipping over the uneven bars, girls leaping over the vault. But on a recent Friday, the class ground to a halt as the girls gathered around Jill Hertzberg, the group leader for campers going into seventh and eighth grades, to discuss the first social of the summer with the boys camp across the lake.

title: DIRECTOR OF F.B.I. DEMOTES DEPUTY
description: F.B.I. Director Louis J. Freeh today demoted the bureau's Deputy Director, Larry A. Potts, citing the turmoil created by an internal investigation into the destruction of documents relating to the conduct of Mr. Potts and other senior F.B.I. officials in a deadly 1992 standoff with a white separatist in Idaho.

title: B-2, After 14 Years, Is Still Failing Basic Tests
description: The $44 billion B-2 bomber has radar that cannot distinguish a raincloud from a mountainside, has not passed most of its basic tests and may not be nearly as stealthy as advertised, according to a draft report by the General Accounting Office, the independent auditing agency of Congress.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about the appointment of Karen L. Katen as president of the United States pharmaceutical unit of Pfizer Inc. misspelled the surname of another top woman executive in the pharmaceutical industry, the vice president and general counsel of Eli Lilly & Company. She is Rebecca O. Goss, not Gross.

title: Maggie Keswick, 53, Expert on Chinese Gardens
description: Maggie Keswick, a Scots-born connoisseur of China and its sensuous, mysterious gardens, died on July 8 in London. She was 53 and had homes in London, Santa Monica, Calif., and Wellfleet, Mass.

title: PRICES ON SOME COPIERS TO BE RAISED BY 3% to 8%
description: The Xerox Corporation will raise prices 3 percent to 8 percent on some copiers as of Aug. 1. Many of its Japanese competitors have raised prices in recent months to combat the yen's rise against the dollar, the company said yesterday. The increased value of the yen has also made Xerox parts in Japan more expensive. Xerox last increased prices on April 1, raising prices on copiers, printers and services 3 percent to 6 percent.

title:
INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Chrysler Cars Go on Sale In Vietnam
description: Just days after President Clinton extended full diplomatic recognition to Vietnam, some flashy symbols of American capitalism -- new Chrysler vehicles -- are now for sale in this country again.

title: California Lottery And Equifax Settle
description: Equifax Inc. said today that it had settled a lawsuit with the California State Lottery, clearing the way for the company to resume work under a contract that could bring Equifax as much as $150 million over the life of the 66-month contract.

title:
INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
At Moscow Plant, Cries of 'We'll Never Sell'
description: Here at the Red October Chocolate Factory, the Russian answer to Hershey's, 2,900 fiercely proud workers are reeling from the first hostile corporate takeover attempt in post-Communist Russia.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball American League BALTIMORE ORIOLES -- Activated Ben McDonald, pitcher, from the 15-day disabled list. Sent Joe Borowski, pitcher, to Rochester of the International League. CLEVELAND INDIANS -- Released Bud Black, pitcher. Called up Albie Lopez, pitcher, from Buffalo of the American Association. MILWAUKEE BREWERS -- Placed Joe Oliver, catcher, on the 15-day disabled list. SEATTLE MARINERS -- Signed Norm Charlton, pitcher. National League ST. LOUIS CARDINALS -- Placed Mike Morgan, pitcher, on the 15-day disabled list. Activated Donovan Osborne, pitcher, from the 15-day disabled list.

title: Talks on Beach Party Restraints
description: Facing criticism over the police shutdown of streets and diversion of cars last Sunday during the annual Greekfest beach party by thousands of black fraternity members, the Mayor and police officials are scheduling more meetings with civil rights organizations. Mayor Kenneth E. Pringle said the police were motivated only by traffic and crowd control concerns when they turned away nonresidents, but some black organizations are calling it racial discrimination. "There are two sets of interests here that are hard to reconcile. There is some resentment on both sides," the Mayor said yesterday.

title: More French Fireworks For Jalabert's Victory
description: Laurent Jalabert lived the dream of every French bicycle racer in the Tour de France today, winning the daily stage on Bastille Day as the national holiday was celebrated with parades, dances, fireworks and enormous crowds at the sides of the road.

title: Can Alternative Medicine Heal? Trials Will Tell
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about Republican efforts to reduce Federal spending omitted part of the House Appropriations Committee's budget proposal for the National Endowment for the Arts. When an allotment for matching grants is included, the proposed budget is $99.5 million, or $62.9 million less than was allotted in 1995; the proposed budget is not $82.2 million.

title: Company Fined In Libya Trade
description: The Halliburton Company said today that it would pay $3.81 million in fines and plead guilty to charges that between 1987 and 1990 it had violated a Federal law banning trade with Libya.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CACI INTERNATIONAL INC., Arlington, Va., an information systems producer, signed a letter of intent to buy the closely held Automated Sciences Group for $5.3 million in cash, payable over three years. GENELABS TECHNOLOGIES INC., Redwood City, Calif., formed a joint pharmaceutical venture under which the Government of Taiwan will invest about $12 million for a 35 percent stake in Genelabs' unit there.

title: Grant for Homeless Projects
description: About $26.7 million in Federal grants to move the homeless from city streets to decent housing and improve job training and mental health services were announced yesterday at the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development's offices here.
